subject: Re: [junit] Preventing JUnit from stopping on failures.
msgSnippet: ... I thought I saw this pattern in your example: arrange act assert act some more assert some more act some more assert some more Ick. If I mis-saw, then

Jason Rogers wrote:
> Jim McMaster wrote:
> [snip]
> 
>  > Oof! You have a much larger definition of "small bit of functionality"
>  > than
>  > I do ;-).  That sounds like a big chunk of an application to me.
> 
> As I said, it was a contrived example... probably not the best.  For
> what it's worth, our application doesn't model things that way.  I was
> using our business logic in a contrived situation to attempt to make a
> point.  However, it only derailed into a critique of the code and such
> -- I'll know better next time.  The point was that asserts may exist
> within a context that are related only by the context itself.  They do
> not affect each other.  For instance, applying a CreditMemo in this case
> will change the amount of a Sale and possibly its CloseDate and Stage. 
> Whether or not the resulting CloseDate was correct has no affect on
> whether or not the resulting amounts of the Sale are correct. 
> Nevertheless, when applying the CreditMemo to a Sale it makes sense to
> assert for all of these things.

I thought I saw this pattern in your example:

arrange
act
assert
act some more
assert some more
act some more
assert some more

Ick.

If I mis-saw, then ignore me happily. You already know when to do that, 
anyway. :)
-- 
J. B. (Joe) Rainsberger
